results.abstract: Inquiry bd releases 3,000-page rept of findings on Apollo fire; says faulty elec wire is probable cause; doubts exact cause will ever be positively identified; scores NASA and N Amer Aviation; Repr Teague 'disappointed' at laxity; rept lists conditions leading to accident, including sealed, pressurized cabin with oxygen atmosphere, extensive use of combustible materials in cabin, vulnerable wiring, vulnerable plumbing carrying combustible, corrosive coolant, inadequate provisions for escape and rescue; finds 'deficiencies in design and engineering, mfr and quality control'; says crew may have been unfamiliar with procedures because of 56 major changes on preceding day; finds checklists unchecked; finds wrench socket left between bundles of wiring; urges new escape hatch be used; bd members listed

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 9--A board of review said today that the fire that killed three astronauts in their Apollo space capsule last Jan. 27 was probably caused by a faulty electrical wire.

headline.main: Coins; A Good 'Money' Policy

results.snippet: WHEN thieves broke  into the New York  home of Ramon De  Biase in 1964, they  stole, among other things, his $1,800 coin collection. The insurance company contended that he was entitled to only $100 compensation for the loss of the collection under...
results.lead_paragraph: WHEN thieves broke into the New York home of Ramon De Biase in 1964, they stole, among other things, his $1,800 coin collection. The insurance company contended that he was entitled to only $100 compensation for the loss of the collection under the terms of the standard 'money theft" clause in his policy.

headline.main: News Summary and Index; The Major Events of the Day

results.snippet: American planes yesterday bombed two military airfields in North Vietnam for the first time in the war, indicating a new stage in the widening air war. Later they attacked a rail yard 2  miles from the center of Hanoi and a transformer site seven...
results.lead_paragraph: American planes yesterday bombed two military airfields in North Vietnam for the first time in the war, indicating a new stage in the widening air war. Later they attacked a rail yard 2 miles from the center of Hanoi and a transformer site seven miles out. The raids were seen as part of an increasing effort to help force Hanoi to negotiate.
